ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained more knowledge about how the legal system works, and how legal decision-makers think.

I developed an understanding of the empirical study of law and legal decision-making. I learned about both the research methodology and about legal decision-making itself. I also gained an understanding of inherent complexity and difficulty of studying legal decision-making in an externally valid way.
Ways to consider evidence processing and biases of those involved in trials.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some of the strengths are Professor Kahan's enthusiasm and genuine interest in the subject matter. A weakness, at least for this iteration of the course, is the general lack of engagement by the majority of the students. Discussion seemed to be dominated by a few students (though this is probably the case for most courses).

I especially enjoyed it when Professor Khan would open the discussion by introducing the topic and providing some background knowledge on the topic area. It was mostly discussion-based, but I thought the discussion went a lot smoother on the days such an introduction happened because students had a better understanding of what to focus on.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course. The readings are interesting and well chosen, and the discussions were fascinating. There was also a diverse mix of undergrads, grad students, and law students in the class; this diversity helped facilitate the discussion.

I would recommend this course to a student that enjoys discussion seminars and is already interested in how law and cognition interact. I don't think every student would enjoy this course though. It seems like a student would get out what they put into this course and those that aren't invested would bring down the morale of the class by not participating.
